description: Just like Goddess Kushmanda, who offers strength and warmth to the universe, the hue orange raises energy and passion, boosting the festive mood to new heights. So, let's have a look at some ideas for letting the orange glow light up your Navratri celebration, from eye-catching décor to tangy bhog offerings and colourful clothing, we have covered everything.

title: Signs of a heart attack in young people
description: Heart attacks among young individuals, especially aged 18-44, are rising alarmingly, even in those leading seemingly healthy lifestyles. Experts highlight that being sedentary, poor diets, and stress are key factors. Early signs include neck and shoulder pain, unusual sweating, and shooting arm pains. Awareness and timely medical consultation can help mitigate risks.

Here, we have got you a unique optical illusion personality test, that, as per yourtango.com reveals your greatest strengths and weaknesses- - based on the first thing that you see in the given picture. description: The 19th-century Hindu monk Swami Vivekananda inspires people worldwide with his timeless words of wisdom even today. Here we list some of his profound quotes that can transform your life too.

title: Navratri Day 4: How to style brown
description: Navratri's fourth day honours Goddess Kushmanda Mata, symbolizing creation, vitality, and prosperity. Devotees often dress in brown, reflecting earthiness and stability. Styling tips include pairing brown with gold accents, vibrant shades, subtle prints, and traditional accessories. Comfortable footwear is essential for the festival's dancing and celebrations. Embrace brown to connect with the divine and festive spirit.

description: Nita Ambani dazzled at Manish Malhotra's store launch in Mumbai, wearing a neon green sari that blended traditional elegance with modern boldness. Her understated yet glamorous sari, luxurious accessories, and meticulous styling highlighted her impeccable taste in fashion, proving that simplicity can be powerful and timeless.

description: Not all signs of intelligence are as obvious as high grades or academic achievements. By recognizing these less common but significant traits, parents can better support and nurture their child's development.

description: Let's take a look at best Navratri hairstyles inspired by Bollywood beauties.

description: This includes Dominguez Blanco’s remarkable shot of a nuthatch climbing down an oak tree, along with stunning images from other winners, including the unique shot by overall winner Patricia Homonylo.

title: 8 simple and tasty potato snacks for Navratri
description: During festivals like Navratri, devotees observing fasts enjoy versatile potato-based snacks. Eight popular options include sabudana vada, aloo tikki, stuffed aloo, aloo chaat, homemade potato chips, aloo bonda, mashed potato balls, and aloo paneer skewers. These snacks are flavorful, filling, and adherent to fasting guidelines.

description: Although there are a number of questions about this subject of interest that still need to be answered, scientists have successfully made progress in classifying them. Let’s explore these classifications in detail, gaining a better understanding of them!

description: Let's take a look at some lehenga ideas to borrow from Bollywood actresses.

title: Only super intelligent can spot a bird in under 12 seconds
description: A challenging optical illusion featuring a hidden baby chick among sheep tests visual acuity and intelligence. Only the keenest eyes can spot the chick in 12 seconds. Beyond entertainment, such illusions improve problem-solving skills, creativity, focus, memory retention, and offer relaxation. The hidden chick blends with the sheep's wool, adding to the difficulty.

title: Inspiration for kids: The story of Pinki Haryan
description: Pinki Haryan's journey from begging on the streets to becoming a physician exemplifies the transformative power of education and support. Her story underscores the importance of parental encouragement in helping children overcome challenges and achieve their dreams, no matter how lofty.

title: Nita and Isha Ambani dazzle together
description: The opening night of the "Wildlife Photographer of the Year" exhibition at Nita Mukesh Ambani Cultural Centre saw Mukesh Ambani, Nita Ambani, Isha Ambani, and Anand Piramal in attendance. The event, marked by elegant fashion choices from Nita and Isha, celebrated the first hosting of the exhibit by NMACC, attracting several high-profile guests.

title: Men of this village dress as women during Navratri
description: Every year during the Navratri, a unique custom takes place in Sadu Mata Ni Pol, a locality in Ahmedabad. On the eighth night of the festival, men from the Barot community put on sarees and perform Garba- - a ceremonial dance. This astonishing tradition has been in practice for over 200 years and is deep-seated in a heart-wrenching story.

title: Sustained rise in antimicrobial resistance in India: ICMR study
description: A study by ICMR revealed that Klebsiella pneumoniae and Acinetobacter baumannii showed resistance to imipenem among ICU patients with bloodstream infections. Staphylococcus aureus and Enterococcus faecium were resistant to oxacillin and vancomycin, respectively. A high resistance rate was also noted in bacteria causing UTIs and pneumonia.

title: What lifestyle changes can help you stay cancer-free?
description: By adopting a healthier lifestyle and being proactive about your health, you can make a meaningful impact on your overall well-being.

title: ICMR to study efficacy of Metformin, Inositol in PCOS treatment
description: India's ICMR will study the efficacy of Metformin and Inositol drugs in improving fertility and birth outcomes in PCOS women. Despite widespread use, evidence on their effectiveness is limited, especially in the Indian context. The multi-centre study will address this knowledge gap.

title: Detox dangers: Why you should reconsider
description: Detoxes lack scientific backing and may be unsafe due to poor regulation. Experts recommend consulting a healthcare professional for personalized, sustainable health solutions instead of relying on detox products.

title: Govt may mandate QR codes to check fake cancer drugs
description: The Indian government plans to require QR codes on all cancer drugs. This step aims to prevent counterfeit medicines and ensure drug authenticity. The Drugs Technical Advisory Board has agreed to the proposal. An amendment to the Drugs Rules, 1945, is necessary before implementation. This move follows earlier efforts to add barcodes on top 300 drug brands.

title: Lupin subsidiary acquires 9 brands South African firm
description: Lupin's subsidiary, in partnership with ImpiloVest, has acquired nine brands from MNI in South Africa, enhancing its portfolio in complementary and alternative medicines. The acquired brands address various health issues, aligning with Lupin's commitment to holistic and sustainable healthcare solutions.

title: Quick access to key HIV drug hinges on waiver of local clinical trials: Experts
description: Faster access to HIV drug lenacapavir in India hinges on the waiver of local clinical trials. Six companies, including three from India, have non-exclusive, royalty-free licenses to produce generic versions. They must apply for waivers to supply the drug locally and in 120 low- and middle-income countries. Approval from the drug regulator is crucial.

title: Emcure Pharmaceuticals partners with Gilead Sciences to produce HIV prevention drug Lenacapavir
description: Emcure Pharmaceuticals has partnered with Gilead Sciences Ireland UC to manufacture and distribute generic lenacapavir for HIV prevention and treatment. This royalty-free agreement focuses on increasing access to the drug in 120 countries, especially resource-limited nations. Emcure aims to provide high-quality, low-cost HIV medication to improve health outcomes globally.

title: CCI clears Rs 13,630 cr Mankind Pharma acquisition of Bharat Serums
description: The Competition Commission of India (CCI) has approved Mankind Pharma's ₹13,630-crore acquisition of Bharat Serums and Vaccines. This acquisition will strengthen Mankind's position in the Indian women's health and fertility drug market. Mankind Pharma and Bharat Serums both specialize in pharmaceutical formulations and healthcare products.

title: Dr Reddy's enters voluntary licensing deal with Gilead for long-acting HIV drug
description: Dr. Reddy’s has partnered with Gilead Sciences to manufacture and market the HIV drug Lenacapavir in India and 120 other countries. The agreement includes developing Lenacapavir for both treatment and potential prevention of HIV. This collaboration aims to make this advanced treatment accessible in regions with high HIV burdens.

title: What are enzymes? Discover their importance in digestion
description: Enzymes are proteins that act as catalysts, accelerating biochemical reactions by breaking down larger molecules into smaller ones. They are essential for various bodily functions, including detoxification, energy conversion, and cellular growth.

title: CK Birla Healthcare eyes $150 million fundraise via stake sale
description: CK Birla Healthcare, part of the CK Birla Group, aims to raise around $150 million by selling a minority stake. Funds will be used for expansion and debt reduction. The healthcare arm, featuring multiple hospitals and IVF centers, recorded a 34% revenue growth in FY24.

title: CCI clears Rs 13,630-cr Mankind Pharma-Bharat Serums Vaccines deal
description: The Competition Commission of India has approved Mankind Pharma's Rs 13,630 crore acquisition of Bharat Serums and Vaccines. This acquisition, which includes a 100% stake, advances Mankind Pharma's position in the women's health and fertility drug market and grants access to critical care products with established R&D platforms.

title: Government looking to tweak regulatory norms for MedTech, pharma sectors: Niti Aayog's VK Paul
description: The Indian government is considering regulatory revisions for the MedTech and pharma sectors and has sought input from the industry. Niti Aayog member VK Paul highlighted the need to update the regulatory framework to support advancements in medical technology and pharma, aiming for enhanced exports and innovation.

title: Sun Pharma, Philogen enter exclusive licensing pact for commercialisation of specialty cancer drug Firbomun
description: Sun Pharma has signed a global licensing deal with Philogen to commercialize Fibromun, an anti-cancer treatment currently in trial for soft tissue sarcoma and glioblastoma. Philogen will complete clinical trials and seek marketing authorization, while Sun Pharma will handle commercialization. Post-commercialization profits will be shared between both companies.

title: Dr Lal PathLabs sets sights on big buys to expand in south
description: "In south, we are open to looking at M&A opportunities, we did (acquisition of) Suburban (Diagnostics in the Western region). It was our first large sized M&A, so we took about two years to figure out the whole integration process, how do we want to run it, lot of management bandwidth went into stabilising and putting into the growth path, right now the management bandwidth is available, cash on the books are available," said Shankha Banerjee, CEO of Dr Lal.

title: Hospitals queue up for NABH's digital accreditation
description: NABH announced that approximately 100 hospitals in India have received digital health accreditation, indicating strong participation in the initiative. This program, featuring multi-level maturity assessments, aims to standardize healthcare processes, improve patient outcomes, and enhance overall efficiency through advanced technology integration.

title: Lupin ties up with Scope Opthalmics to market eyecare products in Mexico
description: Drug maker Lupin has signed a distribution agreement with Ireland-based Scope Ophthalmics to market the Optase range of eye care products in Mexico, aimed at treating conditions like dry eyes, blepharitis, and meibomian gland dysfunction. This deal enhances Lupin’s ophthalmology portfolio while expanding Scope’s presence in Latin America, emphasizing their commitment to improving vision care.

title: Struggling with high Uric Acid? Try these 8 homemade drinks
description: Here are 8 homemade drinks that can naturally help reduce uric acid levels:

title: Dr Reddy's completes acquisition of Haleon's NRT portfolio
description: Dr Reddy's Laboratories has acquired Haleon's global Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) portfolio, excluding the US, for GBP 458 million. This includes top brands like Nicotinell, Nicabate, Thrive, and Habitrol, spanning over 30 countries. The acquisition strengthens Dr Reddy's consumer healthcare segment.

title: Life support withdrawal for terminally ill: IMA flags concerns, says it will put doctors under stress
description: The Indian Medical Association has expressed concerns over new guidelines that put the responsibility of deciding on life support withdrawal on doctors. The draft suggests a dual-board system and family consent for terminally ill patients. This aims to help families make informed choices but may stress doctors.

title: Venus Remedies get market authorisations for two cancer drugs from Morocco, Philippines
description: Venus Remedies Ltd has received marketing authorisations for two key oncology drugs, carboplatin and bortezomib, from Morocco and the Philippines. These approvals are part of the company's strategy to expand its oncology range and meet the growing global demand for cancer treatments, strengthening its position in Southeast Asia and Africa.

title: Linking spurious drugs with legitimate manufacturers has severe reputational, financial impact: IPA
description: The Indian Pharmaceutical Alliance (IPA) has called for a clear distinction between spurious and sub-standard drugs following a CDSCO report listing over 50 products as 'not of standard quality'. Major drug firms like Sun Pharma and Glenmark assert that flagged medicines are counterfeits, not their products. IPA emphasizes the need to protect India's reputation as a reliable medicine supplier.

title: Pharmacology experts promote rational drug use at Kashmir conference
description: Government Medical College in Anantnag hosted a conference of the Indian Society for Rational Pharmacotherapeutics, focusing on advancements in pharmacology and rational drug use. The event aimed to foster collaboration among professionals and improve healthcare outcomes. Notable attendees included Neelofar Khan, Vice Chancellor of University of Kashmir, and other prominent medical experts.

title: Regulatory, policy reforms crucial for future of India's pharma R&D: Report
description: India's regulatory and policy reforms are crucial for the future of pharmaceutical R&D, streamlining approval processes and strengthening IP protections. Despite significant transformation, challenges like inadequate drug regulation capacity and high compliance costs hinder growth. The report suggests promoting India as a hub for pharmaceutical research and development.

title: 1 in every 4 diabetics at serious risk of heart failure: Study
description: Studies in Mumbai and Delhi-NCR reveal that one in four diabetic patients are at serious risk of developing heart failure. Elevated NT-proBNP levels, a key biomarker for early heart failure detection, were found in 15% of patients with high HbA1c scores. Experts emphasize the need for cardiovascular screening in routine diabetes care.

title: Health ministry comes up with new draft guidelines on passive euthanasia
description: The Union Health Ministry's draft guidelines on passive euthanasia suggest doctors should make considered decisions on withdrawing life support for terminally ill patients based on specific conditions. The guidelines aim to ensure decisions are in the patient's best interests, considering factors like brainstem death and informed refusal by the patient or their kin.

title: Monkeypox in India: Key do's and don'ts you need to follow
description: The Health Ministry's guidelines for Monkeypox in India stress isolation, testing, and public awareness while urging prompt reporting of cases.

title: Medical bills in India are rapidly becoming bigger, reveals new index
description: ACKO India Health Insurance Index 2024 reveals a 14% annual rise in healthcare costs, with 62% of expenses paid out of pocket. Delhi leads in kidney disease claims, while Kolkata and Mumbai see high heart disease claims. It emphasised the need for improved health coverage to protect individuals from unexpected health crises.

title: EQT to exit AGS Health, eyes $750 million valuation
description: Swedish fund EQT Partners is set to sell its five-year-old investment in US-based healthcare IT services firm AGS Health, aiming for a valuation of $750 million-$780 million. The sale process, managed by JP Morgan and Bank of America, will launch early next year. AGS Health provides revenue cycle management solutions and employs 12,000 people across multiple locations.

title: Lupin inks pact with Celnova Pharma for distribution of drug in 2 South American nations
description: Lupin's subsidiary has signed a pact with Celnova Pharma to distribute NaMuscla in Argentina and Colombia. The drug treats non-dystrophic myotonic disorders, improving quality of life for patients. Celnova will handle registration, importation, storage, and sales, while Lupin will manufacture and supply the product.

title: Alembic Pharma gets USFDA nod for generic drug used to treat schizophrenia
description: Alembic Pharmaceuticals has received final approval from the USFDA for its generic version of Paliperidone extended-release tablets, used to treat schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder. The approval covers strengths of 1.5 mg, 3 mg, 6 mg, and 9 mg. The market size for these tablets is estimated at USD 48 million for the year ending June 2024.

title: Alkem Labs denies claims of Pan-D, Clavam 625 batches being not-of-standard quality
description: Alkem Laboratories has denied claims that its products Pan-D and Clavam 625 are of substandard quality. The company stated that an investigation revealed the samples flagged by the central drug regulatory authority were spurious and not manufactured by Alkem. Unique features and QR codes have been added to the packaging to distinguish genuine products.

title: Want to make India a reliable pharmacy of world, says Secretary Department of Pharmaceuticals
description: The Indian pharmaceutical industry is emerging as a crucial part of the economy, driven by the success of the Make in India initiative and the Production-Linked Incentive scheme. The sector has seen significant growth in exports and global interest, with many Contract Research, Development, and Manufacturing Organisations establishing operations in India.

title: Sequent Scientific, Viyash Life Sciences announce Rs 8,000 crore merger
description: Sequent Scientific and Viyash Life Sciences have announced a merger, creating a platform with leadership in animal pharmaceuticals and integrated capabilities across the global pharmaceutical market. The merger will expand Sequent's capital base and is expected to enhance marketing presence, facilitate backward integration, and create procurement synergies.

title: Carlyle Group portfolio companies in advanced talks for a potential merger
description: Sequent Scientific, which is in animal health business, posted revenue of around Rs 1,400 crore in FY24. It had earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation of Rs 100 crore. It has seven manufacturing sites in India, Spain, Brazil and Turkey. Viyash was founded in February 2019 by Hari Babu, formerly the chief operating officer of the world's largest generic drug maker, Mylan, now known as Viatris. Viyash posted FY24 revenue of Rs 1,400 crore with ebitda at Rs 150 crore.

title: Suspended eye drops not intended to replace glasses, says Entod CEO
description: Mumbai-based Entod Pharmaceuticals clarified that its eye drop PresVu is not intended to replace reading glasses for presbyopia. This follows the Indian drug regulator's suspension of its manufacture and sale due to unapproved claims. The company's CEO acknowledged the regulator's decision, stating the eye drop is a therapeutic option.

title: Biocon inks licensing, supply pact with Tabuk Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Co
description: Biocon Ltd has signed a licensing and supply agreement with Tabuk Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Company to commercialise its GLP-1 products for diabetes and chronic weight management in select Middle Eastern countries. Tabuk Pharmaceuticals will handle marketing, registration, import, and promotion. The agreement includes potential expansion to other GLP products and localised manufacturing.

title: Did not manufacture drugs flagged in CDSCO report, say leading pharma companies
description: Drug companies like Sun Pharma and Torrent Pharma have refuted claims in a CDSCO report that flagged certain medicines as "counterfeits". They assert their products meet quality standards and are implementing measures like QR codes to ensure authenticity. The CDSCO listed over 50 drugs as "not of standard quality" in its latest report.

title: Torrent Pharma refutes claims product Shelcal 500, failed quality test by CDSCO
description: Torrent Pharmaceuticals has denied claims that its popular product Shelcal 500 failed a quality test by the Central Drug Standards Control Organisation (CDSCO). The company asserts that the sample tested was counterfeit and not manufactured by them. Torrent has implemented QR codes to verify authenticity and submitted a formal response to CDSCO.

title: Krsnaa Diagnostics picks up stake in PPP hospital operator Apulki Healthcare
description: Krsnaa Diagnostics has acquired a 23.53% stake in Apulki Healthcare, which operates cancer and cardiac care hospitals under a public-private partnership model. This strategic move will make Krsnaa the exclusive diagnostics partner for Apulki's hospitals for over 30 years, starting with two advanced facilities in Pune and Mumbai.

title: Intuitive Surgical opens GCC in Bengaluru, to hire 250 people
description: Intuitive Surgical has opened a Global Capability Centre in Bengaluru, employing up to 250 full-time positions across various functions. The centre will support the product lifecycle, including upgrades and customer service. The company's da Vinci robotic surgical system is experiencing growth in India, driven by rising demand for robotic-assisted surgeries.

title: Sequent Scientific, Viyash Life Sciences explore merger worth Rs 7000-8000 cr
description: Sequent Scientific and Viyash Life Sciences are discussing a potential merger valued at Rs. 7000-8000 crore. Both companies' boards will meet to consider the deal, which could offer back-end synergies. Carlyle, a global private equity firm, holds shares in both firms. The merger aims to leverage Viyash's manufacturing capacity for Sequent's benefit.

title: 50 new plants to come up in 2 yrs under pharma, medical device PLI scheme: Official
description: The Indian government plans to establish 50 new greenfield pharma and medical device plants under the PLI scheme within two years. This follows the success of the 'Make in India' initiative, which has already seen 50 such plants become operational, significantly boosting exports and achieving trade balance in bulk drugs.

title: Paracetamol to pantop: CDSCO finds over 50 sub-standard drugs. Check full list of medicines
description: The Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) has flagged over 50 drugs, including Paracetamol, as 'not of standard quality'. The report highlights concerns with various medications such as calcium and vitamin D3 supplements, anti-diabetes pills, and high blood pressure medicines. Some pharmaceutical companies have denied responsibility, claiming the drugs are spurious.

title: OneSource in talks to raise Rs 1,670 crore in pre-listing round
description: OneSource, a TPG Growth-backed specialty pharma CDMO, is in talks with investors to raise $200 million. The company, formerly Stelis Biopharma, was demerged from Strides Pharma and aims to list on BSE and NSE within a year. OneSource plans to reduce debt and expand its manufacturing capabilities.

title: IHH Health eyes acquisitions to grow business: CEO Prem Kumar Nair
description: IHH Healthcare plans to double its bed capacity in India to 10,000 beds over the next 4-5 years through brownfield expansion and acquisitions. The group aims to be among the top three healthcare providers in India, expanding into tier-2 cities while maintaining dual brands Fortis and Gleneagles.

title: Piramal Pharma targets to double revenue in 5 years
description: Piramal Pharma aims to achieve $2 billion in annual revenue with a 25% operating margin by fiscal 2030, driven by its CDMO business. The company plans strategic investments to enhance capabilities in various segments and is also focusing on reducing debt. Currently, CDMO contributes significantly to its revenue.

title: Health expenditure share against GDP increases from 1.13% in FY15 to 1.84% in FY22
description: The government health expenditure in India has increased from 1.13% of GDP in 2014-15 to 1.84% in 2021-22, according to the National Health Account estimates. Government spending on healthcare has tripled, while out-of-pocket expenses have significantly decreased, reflecting positive progress towards financial protection and Universal Health Coverage.

title: Testing of drugs from some nations eased
description: The government has decided to reduce the frequency of testing for drugs imported from certain countries, provided their samples have not failed quality tests in the past five years. Random sampling will be conducted periodically, and any failed samples will lead to increased testing. New sources must undergo compulsory testing.

title: As Bird Flu Spreads, Two New Cases Diagnosed in California
description: Both patients were dairy workers whose illnesses were mild. Investigators are continuing to evaluate the contacts of a Missouri patient who had no exposure to animals.

title: What to Know About Test Alternatives to Colonoscopies for Colon Cancer Screening
description: Doctors can provide alternative forms of screening for colon and rectal cancer but sometimes have a good reason to stick with the colonoscope.

title: Trump Promised to Release His Medical Records. He Still Won’t Do It.
description: If elected again, he would become the oldest president by the end of his term. Yet he is refusing to disclose even basic health information.

title: Gilead Agrees to Allow Generic Version of Groundbreaking H.I.V. Shot in Poor Countries
description: Many middle-income countries are left out of the deal, widening a gulf in access to critical medicines.

title: As America’s Marijuana Use Grows, So Do the Risks
description: The drug, legal in much of the country, is widely seen as nonaddictive and safe. For some users, these assumptions are dangerously wrong.

title: Stories of Marijuana’s Little-Known Harms: ‘It Took Over Everything’
description: A growing number of marijuana users in the U.S. are experiencing severe health problems like these.

title: What to Know About the Marburg Virus Disease Outbreak
description: In Rwanda, 11 deaths have been reported from this rare but deadly disease. Two people tested negative in Germany this week.

title: Officials Cast Doubt on a Dementia Drug, but Human Trials Continue
description: The S.E.C. alleged shortcomings in research said to support the drug, and its developer agreed to a $40 million settlement. Some experts wonder why clinical trials have not been stopped.

title: Breast Cancer Continues to Rise Among Younger Women, Study Finds
description: Death rates are declining among U.S. women with breast cancer. But the disease is turning up more often in women under age 50.

title: Rwanda’s Doctors and Nurses Hit Hard by Deadly Marburg Virus
description: The Health Ministry has reported that 80 percent of the infected are health care professionals.

title: ‘Mom, I Want to Live’: A Young Girl Battles War and Cancer
description: Sonya Liakh was diagnosed with eye cancer at age 2. After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine disrupted her treatment, her family faced a desperate struggle.

title: Nighttime Depression Is a Real Thing
description: There are lots of reasons your mood might tank at night. Here’s how to address the bedtime blues.

title: California Sues Hospital for Denying Patient an Emergency Abortion
description: The state said that despite a doctor’s recommendation and state law, a Catholic hospital declined to provide an abortion because fetal heart tones were present.

title: Rabies Death in Minnesota Linked to Exposure to Bat, Officials Say
description: The death, which was reported on Friday, is only the fifth fatal human rabies case in Minnesota since 1975, health officials said.

title: After Your Death, Who Takes Care of the Dog?
description: A pet trust designates a new guardian for companion animals and sets aside funds for their care. Better yet, it’s legally binding.

title: Viewfinders Make Fall Foliage Pop for the Colorblind in Virginia
description: Specialized viewfinders installed across state parks let visitors with red-green colorblindness see more distinct colors.

title: Biden Officials Stave Off Sticker Shock on Medicare Drug Premiums
description: Federal regulators spent billions of dollars to avoid a spike in costs for older Americans that could have been politically damaging to the presidential campaign of Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: Possible Cluster of Human Bird-Flu Infections Expands in Missouri
description: Seven people in contact with a patient hospitalized with bird flu also developed symptoms, the C.D.C. reported. Some are undergoing further tests.

title: Acadia Healthcare Says It Faces New Federal Investigations
description: Shares of the company, one of the largest chains of for-profit psychiatric hospitals, were down 25 percent at one point.

title: Risk of Heart Defects Higher in Babies Conceived With I.V.F.
description: The birth defects were more likely, but still very uncommon, in infants conceived through certain fertility treatments, a large study found.

title: Convenience store giants fight Health Canada’s nicotine pouch rules
description: Convenience store firms across Canada are taking the federal government to court to overturn regulations that restrict the sale of nicotine pouches to pharmacies.

title: Invisible killer: What is antimicrobial resistance?

Everyone seems to have had a family member or friend who has either gotten seriously ill or died due to acquiring an infection that did not respond to prescribed medicines, and the underlying reason was often antimicrobial resistance. Yet, there are many ways of addressing this threat, from hygiene and sanitation to vaccination and avoiding overuse or misuse of medicines.
